byline.contributor: Christopher Drew reported from Creech Air Force Base, and Dave Philipps from New York. Mark Mazzetti and Eric Schmitt contributed reporting from Washington.
byline.original: By CHRISTOPHER DREW and DAVE PHILIPPS

abstract: Air Force is being forced to cut back on daily number of drone flights in overseas conflict zones due to operator burnout, even as military and intelligence officials are requesting increase in number of flights needed to handle escalating clashes; wave of remote pilots, worn out by job's unique stresses, are choosing to retire once their obligation to Air Force is complete.
lead_paragraph: Long hours and the psychological toll of the work have forced the Pentagon to abandon its goal of increasing the flights and to instead reduce the number.

headline.main: As Stress Drives Off Drone Operators, Air Force Must Cut Flights
headline.print_headline: Burnout Forces U.S. to Curtail Drone Flights

snippet: Long hours and the psychological toll of the work have forced the Pentagon to abandon its goal of increasing the flights and to instead reduce the number.

keywords.value: United States Defense and Military Forces
